course.subject: ECON
course.name: Managerial Macroeconomics
course.description: This course modifies and extends the standard models studied in introductory macroeconomics course (2123), highlighting the role of expectations in determining the aggregate output, the inflation, and the asset prices. The course consists of two parts: (A) lectures on the models and their applications on the economics issues such as monetary and fiscal policies, financial crises, and exchange rate policies; and (B) group research projects undertaken by the students to apply macro models, statistical and econometrics tools to analyze a real-world question of their pick, in order to gain better understanding of the models and to practise the skills on problem solving, team-work and presentation.
course.prerequisites: ECON 2123 AND ECON 3334
course.exclusions: ECON 3123, ECON 3143

reviews.author: Testing1234
reviews.title: Finding good group mates is the most important thing
reviews.comment_content:
1. Monetary Policy
2. Extended IS-LM
3. The Crisis
4. Financial Markets and Expectations
5. IS-LM-PC
6. Exchange Rate Regimes

There aren't many topics covered in this course, as the project is the key component of this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I'll split the review in 2 parts.
For the lecture, professor Lu delivers the content clearly. She raised different examples to help us understanding the topics. Topics covered in this course are closely related to daily life, and professor Lu teaches them in a clear and good way.
For the project, professor Lu also helps a lot. She provides detailed suggestions and feedback about how to work on the project. I'll mention more about the project in the Workload part.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 grading schemes, the one with higher score will be chosen.
1. 50% midterm + 50% project
2. 100% project
The grading for the project is further evaluated as follows:
Research plan & reading list 10%
Proposal Presentation 10%
Draft term paper 20%
Paper Presentation 15%
Response/Revision Presentation 10%
The term paper 20%
Peer evaluation by group mates 15%

If you want good grades, FIND GOOD GROUPMATES!!

I'll mention more about the terrible experience of this project. In short, I spent 200% effort to work on the project and secure a good score. The score of all components of the project are above mean, and I scored 93 in the midterm (mean 67.86, UQ 85, LQ 58, max 96). Overall I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
I give a "C" for workload because it's the average score if you have good or bad groupmates. If you have good groupmates, you guys can work together and share the workload, then it will be an "A". If you have terrible groupmates, who don't show up in EVERYTHING, the workload will be an "E".
I strongly recommend you to find groupmates with good Econometrics background. In this project, you'll have to find data, build models, run regressions, do analysis etc. Having good grades in ECON3334 isn't a must, but I'm sure it does help.

If you have bad groupmates, you can treat you're taking Econ4670 and you have to write a term paper by yourself.

I don't wanna blame my groupmates anymore, I gave up on them for a long time. The actual situation is 10 times worse than what I've said here. So please bare in mind: FIND GOOD GROUPMATES!!

reviews.author: economist
reviews.title: Too much on project and too little on economic theory
reviews.comment_content:
I have put the highlights next to the topics
1) Monetary Policy (Mcs, liquidity trap i.e. zero interest rate, indifferent between holding bonds or money)
2) Extended IS-LM (Mcs, SQs, LM curve flattens as it reflected target interest rate)
3) Crisis (MCs, SQs, leverage ratio, debt ratio, MBS)
4) Financial Market Expectation (SQs, discount cash flow problem)
5) Philips Curve (MCs, SQs, original vs modified curve)
6) ISLMPC (LQ in Final, prepare to do some training in it!)
7) Exchange rate (cut in this semester due to protests)

reviews.comment_grading:
(Project score not released)
Better than expected given that few people in the class.

Scheme2: 50% Project + 50% Exam

3. Make sure you write long comments for other groups in the presentation. Bonus marks are granted. My group gets two bonus points due to this policy.

reviews.author: Happypig375
reviews.title: Just form a group of ECON3334 A rangers then you can learn nothing and get A range lol (fuck this grading)
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture topics themselves were highly related to real life. But too much focus on the project which isn't even purely about macroeconomic theory.

A for lecture content, C for project, take B as average.

Syllabus here: https://econ.hkust.edu.hk/sites/economics/files/courses/ugcourses2223/ECON3024.pdf
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures (Prof Lu Yang) and tutorials (TA Astor Fok) were helpful. But the tutorials, iPRS questions and group exercises were far more helpful to the exam than the lecture content which included too much off topic information.  It's just that the professor included lots of other content that I wasted time studying especially the complex stocks equations that did not matter in the end despite "everything will be in the exam". But those are minor problems. The main gripe I have with this course is regarding the assessments especially the group project.
reviews.comment_grading:
UPDATE: My groupmates gave me 4/15 in peer eval and the prof won't review any scores. I encourage you to give your groupmates the lowest of lowest scores because there is zero checking against evaluations that only aim to harm other people. ðŸ« ðŸ« ðŸ« 

+1sd in midterm exam, get C-, "better grade than you think" (said by professor to me) my ass
50% exam + 50% project or 100% project
My grades are here. https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876155439476277309/1113144283160129617/my_grade.png
Syllabus here. https://econ.hkust.edu.hk/sites/economics/files/courses/ugcourses2223/ECON3024.pdf
In what world does +1sd in exam and a few points below mean in project get me a C-?? And this is a 4cred course. 4cred C-. Fuck.

I hate that feedback were limited unless you specifically emailed the professor. The professor won't give helpful directions regarding the exam, while she was unexpectedly lenient in giving away project directions even for some groups' presentations for the next day. Officially in consultation hours, the directions about the presentations won't directly help the project marks, and the only reason for why project marks were low was "not as good as other groups" without clearly listing what major points to improve that directly help the marks. Unofficial emails were somehow much more helpful. It was a mess trying to figure out what the professor wanted even if we thought our work was enough. For such a large part of the grade, more specific directions would have been much preferred, especially for the breakdown of each grade. Despite sharing the proposals, draft papers, and presentations from other groups, the professor somehow does not want to share how the merit points were given to the best group and what criteria constituted meritable comments. Even for the "recommended papers" in the resource repository, no associated marks were listed to judge if the paper really did score the best in its semester. Trying to follow it ended up with marks less than satisfactory.

Exam time was too limited for 50% of the grade and it was rushed. It was not enough to offset the risks involved in the group project. The claim that "the exam won't lower your grade and will only improve your grade" is unverifiable without past data and what past comments for this course does have from outside sources (disregarding what was included by the professor since those are obviously hand picked by the professor to be biased towards agreement), is that only relying on the research project will land a poor grade (B- or below). There were just too little emphasis on economic theories and too much on a group project which has little to do with the lecutre or tutorial content themselves, instead much more related to ECON3334.

The course overemphasised on the project with all the shared information from the other groups and yet underemphasised the topics covered using 2 whole months with all the unshared recordings which only constitutes 50% of the grade. I understand the professor's perspective of ChatGPT making exams and intaking existing knowledge obsolete but we don't need 3 required courses for economics writing and research - ECON3024/3700/4670 especially this one which heavily depends on the groupmates assigned therefore cannot even fulfill ECON4670. (This is also what I hate about some of the 4000 level courses but at least they are not required courses and can fulfill ECON4670.) We also do not need a parallel system of research courses specifically required by the Economics department along the UROP system. It's great that ECON3700 will replace ECON4670 but it should have integrated with this required course better.

By the way, if the professor had not put too much stress on the group project, more students would have had time to raise the SFQ response rate (7 out of 41 at the time of writing) for her. How ironic.

Before you start the course, you should probably look at the mind maps and final papers in the resource repository here first https://www.notion.so/Resource-Repository-46c016fc53134d919c1679fd38672376
reviews.comment_workload: At the last month, hours per meeting long into night, a few days per week for the project. But not much for other parts of the course.

reviews.author: Szczesny
reviews.title: A brand new syllabus was introduced in 18-19 FALL
reviews.comment_content:
In 2018-19 FALL, a whole new syllabus was introduced by Professor Lu

Only mid-term and group project, no final exam.

This course was divided into two parts:
Pre-midterm and Post-midterm

Content covered in the pre-midterm period is an extension of ECON2123, which covers:

1. Monetary policy
2. Phillips curve
3. IS-LM-PC model
4. Exchange rate regimes
5. Financial markets and expectations

No memorizing is required, some students may find it hard to follow at first, and review after lessons are required. After you understand the logical flow behind the concepts, things should be easy.

The mid-term coverage was up to topic 5, while the remaining three topics were meant to give some insights to students for the group project, as mentioned by Professor Lu.

6. Financial crisis
7. Chinaâ€™s RMB exchange rate
8. Technology progress and unemployment
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Lu was simply rushing throughout the pre-midterm period due to the tight schedule. The pace was really hard to follow, and we were like attending a MBA lecture LOL, everyone of us look utterly puzzled and confused after every lecture. The material is not straightforward and requires quite some time to digest, luckily we got lecture videos for revision.

Professor Lu liked to illustrate the logic behind different concepts by drawing diagrams in class, that made the material clearer to us.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since 18-19 FALL ECON3024 is the first ever semester to have the new syllabus implemented, everything is experimental. I guess that's why Professor LU is quite lenient this time in grading.

The grading policy:
1. 50% midterm
2. 50% group project
- 5% research plan
- 10% draft paper
- 20% 2 presentations (Pren-tation as pronounced by Professor LOL)
- 10% final term paper
- 5% peer-evaluation

I was honestly quite scared when I saw group project weighs 50%. That means your grade is highly depend on your project topic and of course, your group-mate.

Midterm will be quite easy if you can thoroughly understand what Professor taught in class, the midterm was easier than expected, and I got 93/100 (Max:99/100; median: 72/100)

There was two grading path that a student can choose:
50% midterm+50% project
or 100% project (risky option)

Basically we have two chances to decide whether to shift the whole 100% to the project. If a student skip the midterm for any reasons, all the weighting are automatically shifted to the group project. The second chance is granted after the midterm result is released, Professor Lu let students have their grade wholly depend group project (of course that is a little bit unfair for students who study hard for the midterm).

5-6 students in a project group, and the group should focus on a topic related to macroeconomics, which does not limited to the concepts taught in class. That's why you can still achieve a A range if you attend none of the lectures and only focus on the group project.

Sometimes it was hard to judge whether Professor Lu was really appreciating your group's work or not, as she gave the similar comments to all group in the project presentation (like well done, good job). You thought you did a great job in the beginning stage of the project as professor gave you positive comments, and confident in shifting all the weighting to the group project. Then you may ruin your grade at last (that's my group-mates' case lol, project mean:33/50 max:40/50, my group:31/50)

My final grade is A-

Considering I got below mean in my 50% of grading, and I could still secure a A-, I think Professor Lu is very lenient in grading this time. My group-mates who shift all the weighting to group project (below mean) got B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you are to decide shift all the weighting to the group project. There is no need for you to attend the class. The only workload from the course is the group project, however, the group project can be of heavy workload since the group has to submit a 3000-word report by the end of the semester. The group project requires quite a lot of effort and time to complete. But again, all-in group project is very risky and it's like betting (that means thrilling LOL)

If you pursue the 50-50 path, you need extra effort to manage the midterm, if you are decent in economics and logical thinking, the revision for mid-term examination should not take more than 4 hours per topics, that means 20 hours in maximum.

Overall speaking, the workload is medium to quite heavy.

I have read some of the reviews before, apparently she has improved quite much, adding some real-life applications here and there.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She was able to guide you through the content, pause to wait for questions and answer them after class.
But she did quite rush through the later half of the course, barely finish it so we didn't have a summary course.
The stuff she teaches differs a bit from the TAs. I recommend to stick to her way of understanding first.
reviews.comment_grading:
Her way of writing the exams (eg: homework, final) sometimes could be very confusing, some part of the grading will depend on your comprehension.
All in all, I do think her grading is fair. got full marks in midterm and homework, top 5 in final, got A+. (total 60+ students)
